newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary delays energy price hike - spokesman.
newsitem.headline: Hungary delays energy price hike - spokesman.

text.p: The Hungarian government has postponed until January 1, 1997 an energy price rise previously announced for October 1, a government official said on Thursday.

"The cabinet could not accept the results of the study on which it would have based the price rise," government spokesman Elemer Kiss told a news conference following Thursday's regular cabinet meeting.
Kiss declined to reveal figures about the amount of any proposed increase, but press reports said that the National Energy Office had proposed a 40 percent energy rise.
A government official will review the study, Kiss added.

He said the January date still meets a deadline stipulated in the energy law, by which time companies which bought stakes in formerly state-owned regional distribution companies are guaranteed an eight percent profit margin.
The rejected study was done by the Industry and Trade Ministry whose minister Imre Dunai resigned last week, quoting health problems.

On the day of his resignation Hungarian radio said Dunai, an independent named to the post by Horn's Socialist Party, may have wanted a bigger hike than the government thought would be acceptable to the general public.
Last December Hungary sold stakes in the six regional electricity distribution companies and two power stations to such western giants as RWE of Germany and Electricite de France (EDF).

The government is bound by a decree passed in 1995 to introduce market prices at the start of next year. The prices, calculated using a complex formula, are supposed to guarantee the investors an eight percent profit.
